Argh. Years back I was a contractor for the DoD. This statement means 
one of a few possible things:

1. "We don't know what jUnit it, so we're against it"
2. "We heard of something like jUnit that is actually banned, so just in 
case we'll say jUnit is banned too."
3. "It's late, let's go home."

I would suggest that since none of the people here who work with jUnit 
have heard of this ban, plus jUnit is pretty much the standard, the 
people making the claim must corroborate it to a *legally* binding 
degree. Nothing like a "well I heard on the internet that..." or "some 
guy who works at some other location says..." but a copy of an actual 
memo or directive that explicitly names jUnit and explains the reason 
for the ban.

Otherwise, I would simply be a good negotiator, viz., expressions of 
sympathy (they are free) but don't give in to whatever they say until 
they document it.

---> Exceptional claims require exceptional proof <---

Note that you should strongly take the position that jUnit is allowed, 
it is the standard and that *they* must prove their claim. Otherwise you 
will be trying to show a negative, which is impossible and will eat up a 
lot of your time in the process.  What will you do if you come up 
empty-handed and they say they think the memo was actually classified? 
If they are legitimate programmers then you'll get this settled pretty 
quickly and amicably. If they are non-technical but in charge, well... 
best of luck....

Jeff

David McReynolds wrote:
>
> Someone popped up at a meeting this morning and announced that the US
> DoD does not allow the use of jUnit for unit testing.
>


> First, I find
> that a little hard to swallow given the second statement about junit
> being the built-in testing generator provided by java (can you say
> non-sequitor?). Secondly, I cannot corroborate that statement via google.
>
> What I need is link to a document that explicitly corroborates or
> refutes the statement. So far, it looks like the statement is false
> but I am only using deductive reasoning there.
>
>
